awd_abstract_narration:
This research project explores the geometry of fractal spaces. Many natural phenomena exhibit fractal features, including lightning bolts, growth patterns of plants and crystals, snowflakes, coastlines, and river networks.  In mathematics, fractal objects arise in the study of dynamical systems such as Julia sets of rational maps, limit sets of Kleinian groups, and attractors in iterated function systems, as well as in probabilistic models such as continuum random trees. The goal of this project is to develop better analytic and geometric tools for an improved understanding of fractals.  The involvement of young researchers in this activity will contribute to increasing the expertise in the field and will help to maintain a scientific community with the mathematical knowledge necessary for progress. 

The project consists of three parts, concerning trees in dynamics and probability, expanding Thurston maps, and solenoids in dynamics.  In each of these subprojects, geometric aspects of fractal spaces are studied that are related to their quasiconformal geometry. One is interested in geometric features that only depend on relative shape sizes and are scale invariant. In more technical terms, this means that one wants to study the geometry of the relevant spaces up to quasisymmetric equivalence. In the past, this conceptual framework has been quite successful for the study of geometric properties of self-similar fractals; the project focuses on some open questions that seem particularly amenable to further investigation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project was part of the PI's ongoing study of various aspects of the analysis and geometry of  fractal  spaces. While many fractal-like objects appear in nature (such lightning bolts, snowflakes, coast lines, etc.), this research was aimed at a better understanding of some of the mathematical foundations of fratal geometry.  A specific focus of the investigations was the  geometry of fractals appearing in dynamical systems such as Julia sets of rational maps or attractors of iterated function systems.  

Intellectual merit: Among one of the fractals studied in depth was the continuum self-similar tree (CSST). It appears in many settings in dynamics and probability. The project led to a complete understanding of the topology and quasiconformal geometry of the CSST.  Another main topic was the dynamics of expanding Thurston maps and the geometry of their associated fractal 2-spheres. This is a rich and fertile subject with connections to Teichmüller theory, hyperbolic geometry, analysis on metric spaces, and other areas. The project resulted in ten publications by the PI and his collaborators, and several publications by his PhD students.

Broader impact:  The development of human resources was an important aspect of this project. Two dissertations were completed by PhD students working under the PI's supervision. The PI also sponsored  undergraduate research and (co)-organized several conferences and workshops related to dynamics and quasiconformal geometry.


Last Modified: 09/07/2021
Modified by: Mario Bonk
